name: Epidural Steroid Injections for Pain Management
description: This policy outlines the coverage, limitations, and medical necessity criteria for epidural steroid injections (ESIs) for pain management, addressing indications, procedural requirements, dosage limitations, and contraindications.

restrictions.condition: Diagnosis of lumbar radiculopathy, cervical radiculopathy, thoracic radiculopathy, radicular pain, or neurogenic claudication, supported by history, physical examination, and concordant radiological imaging, due to disc herniation, osteophyte, osteophyte complexes, severe degenerative disc disease, or producing foraminal or central spinal stenosis.
restrictions.rule: (diagnosis_radiculopathy_lumbar = TRUE OR diagnosis_radiculopathy_cervical = TRUE OR diagnosis_radiculopathy_thoracic = TRUE OR diagnosis_radicular_pain = TRUE OR diagnosis_neurogenic_claudication = TRUE) AND (diagnosis_disc_herniation = TRUE OR diagnosis_osteophyte = TRUE OR diagnosis_osteophyte_complex = TRUE OR diagnosis_degenerative_disc_disease_severe = TRUE OR diagnosis_spinal_stenosis_foraminal = TRUE OR diagnosis_spinal_stenosis_central = TRUE)

restrictions.condition: Diagnosis of post-laminectomy syndrome, supported by history, physical examination, and concordant radiological imaging.
Diagnosis of acute herpes zoster associated pain, supported by history, physical examination, and concordant radiological imaging.
Radiculopathy, radicular pain, or neurogenic claudication must be severe enough to greatly impact quality of life or function.
restrictions.rule: (diagnosis_radiculopathy_lumbar = TRUE OR diagnosis_radiculopathy_cervical = TRUE OR diagnosis_radiculopathy_thoracic = TRUE OR diagnosis_radicular_pain = TRUE OR diagnosis_neurogenic_claudication = TRUE) AND (functional_assessment_baseline_required_flag = TRUE OR pain_scale_baseline_required_flag = TRUE)

restrictions.condition: An objective pain scale or functional assessment must be performed at baseline prior to interventions.
The same objective pain scale or functional assessment used at baseline must be repeated at each follow-up for assessment of response.
Pain duration must be at least four weeks.

Inability to tolerate noninvasive conservative care, OR medical documentation of failure to respond to four weeks of noninvasive conservative care, OR acute herpes zoster refractory to conservative management where a four-week wait is not required.
Epidural steroid injections must be performed under CT or fluoroscopy image guidance with contrast, unless a documented contraindication exists.
restrictions.rule: ((procedure_image_guidance_CT = TRUE OR procedure_image_guidance_fluoroscopy = TRUE) AND substance_contrast_media = TRUE) OR (patient_contrast_allergy_flag = TRUE AND procedure_image_guidance_ultrasound = TRUE AND substance_contrast_media = FALSE) OR (patient_pregnancy_flag = TRUE AND procedure_image_guidance_ultrasound = TRUE AND substance_contrast_media = FALSE)

restrictions.condition: Transforaminal epidural steroid injections (TFESIs) are limited to a maximum of two levels in one spinal region.
Caudal epidural steroid injections (CESIs) are limited to a maximum of one level.
Interlaminar epidural steroid injections (ILESIs) are limited to a maximum of one level.
Transforaminal epidural steroid injections (TFESIs) may be performed bilaterally only when clinically indicated.

Repeat ESI is considered if the first injection provided at least 50% sustained improvement in pain relief for at least three months, OR at least 50% objective improvement in function for at least three months.
If an initial ESI fails, a repeat ESI can be performed after 14 days, using a different approach, level, or medication, with documented rationale.
An initial injection of contrast is required to confirm epidural placement, unless contraindicated.
Subsequent epidural steroid injections must include corticosteroids.
Epidural steroid injections should be performed in conjunction with conservative treatments.
Patient should be part of an active rehabilitation program, home exercise program, or functional restoration program.
ESIs performed with biologicals or other substances not FDA designated for this use are considered investigational and not medically reasonable and necessary.

Performing multiple blocks (ESI, sympathetic blocks, facet blocks, trigger point injections etc.) during the same session as ESIs is generally not medically reasonable and necessary, with the exception of a facet synovial cyst and ESI performed in the same session.
Use of Moderate or Deep Sedation, General Anesthesia, and Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC) is generally not medically reasonable and necessary for ESI procedures.
restrictions.rule: procedure_sedation_level IN ('Moderate Sedation','Deep Sedation','General Anesthesia','Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC)')

restrictions.condition: ESIs to treat non-specific low back pain (LBP) are considered investigational and not medically reasonable and necessary.
ESIs to treat axial spine pain are considered investigational and not medically reasonable and necessary.
ESIs to treat complex regional pain syndrome are considered investigational and not medically reasonable and necessary.
ESIs to treat widespread diffuse pain are considered investigational and not medically reasonable and necessary.
ESIs to treat pain from neuropathy from other causes are considered investigational and not medically reasonable and necessary.
ESIs to treat cervicogenic headaches are considered investigational and not medically reasonable and necessary.
ESIs are limited to a maximum of four sessions per spinal region in a rolling twelve-month period.
It is not medically reasonable and necessary for more than one spinal region to be injected in the same session.
It is not medically reasonable and necessary to perform TFESIs at more than two nerve root levels during the same session.
It is not medically reasonable and necessary to perform CESIs or ILESIs at more than one level during the same session.
It is not medically reasonable and necessary to perform CESIs bilaterally.
It is not medically reasonable and necessary to perform ILESIs bilaterally.
It is not medically reasonable and necessary to prescribe a predetermined series of ESIs.
Recommended not to exceed 80 mg of triamcinolone per session.
Recommended not to exceed 12 mg of betamethasone per session.
Recommended not to exceed 15 mg of dexamethasone per session.
Treatment with ESI generally not considered medically reasonable and necessary beyond 12 months.
For continuation of ESIs beyond 12 months, patient has severe functional or vocational disability.
For continuation of ESIs beyond 12 months, ESI must provide at least 50% sustained improvement of pain and/or 50% objective improvement in function (using same scale as baseline).

For continuation of ESIs beyond 12 months, rationale for continuation (e.g., high-risk surgical candidate, patient does not desire surgery, recurrence of pain relieved for at least three months) must be documented.
For continuation of ESIs beyond 12 months, the primary care provider must be notified regarding continuation of procedures and prolonged repeat steroid use.
ESIs are contraindicated if there is a suspected or active localized spinal infection.
ESIs are contraindicated if there is a significant systemic infection.
ESIs are contraindicated if there are compressive lesions of the spinal cord.
ESIs are contraindicated if there are compressive lesions of the conus medullaris.
ESIs are contraindicated if there are compressive lesions of the cauda equina.
ESIs are contraindicated if there is suspicion or major risk factors for cancer.
Services must be performed by appropriately trained providers.
Credentialing or privileges are required for procedures performed in inpatient and outpatient settings.
All aspects of care must be within the provider’s medical licensure and scope of practice.
Providers must meet training requirements for using and interpreting imaging modalities (ionizing radiation and associated contrast material, magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasound).
Imaging (MRI of lumbar spine without contrast or CT if MRI unavailable) may be considered for patients with no improvement in back pain after six weeks of medical management and physical therapy.
Absolute contraindication: coagulopathy not correctible.
Absolute contraindication: concurrent systemic infection.
Absolute contraindication: infectious spondylitis.
Absolute contraindication: acute spinal cord compression.
Absolute contraindication: myelopathy.
Absolute contraindication: cauda equina syndrome.
Absolute contraindication: inability to obtain informed consent.
Absolute contraindication: infection at the skin puncture site.
Relative contraindication: uncorrected anticoagulation therapy.
Relative contraindication: hypersensitivity to administered agents.
Relative contraindication: pregnancy.
Relative contraindication: hepatitis (thrombocytopenia must be excluded).
Relative contraindication: uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (risk of elevated blood sugars after steroid injections).
Relative contraindication: congestive heart failure (steroid may lead to fluid retention).
Relative contraindication: immunosuppressed state (preprocedural antibiotics may be considered).
Relative contraindication: patient improving on medical and physical therapy.
Relative contraindication: severe spinal canal stenosis.
Relative contraindication: no response to previous well-performed ESI.
Relative contraindication: complication to steroid therapy (Cushing’s etc.).
Recommended lowest effective dosing for methylprednisolone acetate (MPA) is 40mg.
Recommended lowest effective dosing for triamcinolone acetate is 10-20mg.
Recommended lowest effective dosing for dexamethasone phosphate is 10mg (10mg/mL).
Recommended to limit cervical interlaminar and lumbar transforaminal injection volume to 4mL.
Etanercept is not FDA approved for injection into the epidural space.
No more than 4 ESIs and/or Selective Nerve Root Blocks (SSNBs) should be performed in a 6-month period.
No more than 6 ESIs and/or Selective Nerve Root Blocks (SSNBs) should be performed in a 12-month period, regardless of the number of levels.
No more than 2 TFESIs should be performed at a single setting (e.g., single level bilaterally or two levels).
For CESIs or ILESIs, only one level per session may be performed and NOT in conjunction with a TFESI injection.
